Experiment A:
Alex was standing in the doorway of a room on the right. He crooked a finger at Bond in a silent, spidery summons.
Alex was being led down a passage towards the back of the house. Bond suddenly decided. With a backward kick which connected with the thin man’s shins and brought a whistle of pain from him, Bond hurled himself down the passage after her. His plan was to do as much damage as possible to the two gunmen and be able to exchange a few hurried words with the girl.
Like lightning the Corsican slammed himself back against the wall of the passage and, as Bond’s foot whistled past his hip, he very quickly, but somehow delicately, shot out his left hand, caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc, and twisted it sharply. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion that he hoped went unnoticed, moved his fountain pen deeper into his breast pocket, he righted himself with minimal damage.
“Search him.” barked Alex.
The two gunmen dragged Bond to his feet. While the thin man kept his gun trained on Bond’s unquiet chest, the Corsican roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. He twisted Bond around brusquely in search of other weaponry. Alex observed his assistant’s work attentively. Then, as if reading Bond’s thoughts, he crossed the room and said, “Come my dear friend. Let’s not waste time.”

Taylor was standing in the doorway of a room on the right. He crooked a finger at Bond in a silent, spidery summons.
Jordan was being led down a passage towards the back of the house. Bond suddenly decided. With a backward kick which connected with the thin man’s shins and brought a whistle of pain from him, Bond hurled himself down the passage after her. His plan was to do as much damage as possible to the two gunmen and be able to exchange a few hurried words with the girl.
Like lightning the Corsican slammed himself back against the wall of the passage and, as Bond’s foot whistled past his hip, he very quickly, but somehow delicately, shot out his left hand, caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc, and twisted it sharply. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion that he hoped went unnoticed, moved his fountain pen deeper into his breast pocket, he righted himself with minimal damage.
“Search him.” barked Taylor.
The two gunmen dragged Bond to his feet. While the thin man kept his gun trained on Bond’s unquiet chest, the Corsican roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. He twisted Bond around brusquely in search of other weaponry. Taylor observed his assistant’s work attentively. Then, as if reading Bond’s thoughts, he crossed the room and snatched away Bond’s fountain pen. “Come my dear friend,” said Taylor. “Let’s not waste time.”

Jordan was standing in the doorway of a room on the right. He crooked a finger at Bond in a silent, spidery summons.
Jordan was being led down a passage towards the back of the house. Bond suddenly decided. With a backward kick which connected with the thin man’s shins and brought a whistle of pain from him, Bond hurled himself down the passage after her. His plan was to do as much damage as possible to the two gunmen and be able to exchange a few hurried words with the girl.
Like lightning the Corsican slammed himself back against the wall of the passage and, as Bond’s foot whistled past his hip, he very quickly, but somehow delicately, shot out his left hand, caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc, and twisted it sharply. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion in which he took great pride, he righted himself with minimal damage.
“Search him.” barked Jordan.
The two gunmen dragged Bond to his feet. While the thin man kept his gun trained on Bond’s unquiet chest, the Corsican roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. He twisted Bond around brusquely in search of other weaponry. Jordan observed his assistant’s work attentively. Then, as if reading Bond’s thoughts, he crossed the room and said, “Come my dear friend. Let’s not waste time.”
Experiment B:
Filled with confidence after defeating Alex, Bond had extended an invitation to Vesper to dine with him in the hotel restaurant. She had cheerfully accepted.
Bond looked in the mirror of his hotel room to make certain that his black tie was centered in his collar. He noticed that he had a white thread on his lapel, and removed it. Bond smiled at the elegant figure he presented.
As Bond turned to leave the room, the door burst in toward him. Three large men leapt through, guns drawn. The largest of the men was Alex, Bond’s recently vanquished opponent.
As the three men approached him, Bond suddenly whirled around and caught one of the gunmen squarely in the stomach with a well-placed shove of his heel. Unfortunately, the second gunman had accurately judged the rest of Bond’s motion. He caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc and twisted it sharply. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion in which he took great pride, he righted himself with minimal damage. Bond was unharmed, but he was trapped.
“Search him.” barked Alex.
The two gunmen carefully searched Bond. They roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. They twisted him around in search of other weaponry.
Alex observed his assistants' work attentively. He crossed the room to Bond, and patted him down once again. Alex pulled out Bond’s pocket comb and ran his finger down its teeth. He smiled broadly, and flipped the comb well out of Bond’s reach. “Come, my dear friend,” said Alex. “Let’s not waste time.”
Bond felt puny and impotent.

Filled with confidence after defeating Morgan, Bond had extended an invitation to Vesper to dine with him in the hotel restaurant. She had cheerfully accepted.
Bond looked in the mirror of his hotel room to make certain that his black tie was centered in his collar. He noticed that his hair was just the least bit mussed, so he extracted his comb from his pocket and smoothed his wandering locks back into place.
As Bond turned to leave the room, the door burst in toward him. Three large men leapt through, guns drawn. The largest of the men was Morgan, Bond’s recently vanquished opponent.
As the three men approached him, Bond suddenly whirled around and caught one of the gunmen squarely in the stomach with a well-placed shove of his heel. Unfortunately, the second gunman had accurately judged the rest of Bond’s motion. He caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc and twisted it sharply. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion in which he took great pride, he righted himself with minimal damage. Bond was unharmed, but he was trapped.
“Search him.” barked Morgan.
The two gunmen carefully searched Bond. They roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. They twisted him around in search of other weaponry.
Morgan observed his assistants' work attentively. He crossed the room to Bond, and patted him down once again. Morgan pulled out Bond’s pocket comb and ran his finger down its teeth. He smiled broadly, and flipped the comb well out of Bond’s reach. “Come, my dear friend,” said Morgan. “Let’s not waste time.”
Bond felt puny and impotent.
Experiment C:
Riley smiled and said, “We must stop meeting like this Mr. Alex. I grow weary of pointing a gun at you.”
Before Alex could reply, a large bird crashed into the wall of glass that made up one side of Riley’s large office. Alex took advantage of the distraction to pull up one corner of the rug on which Riley stood. Riley stumbled backwards and his gun shot up into the air, knocking out the large light that had illuminated the room.
As Alex’s eyes grew accustomed to the dark of the office, he hurried toward the door. He was met there, however, by a very large and very ugly man. Light from the hall spilled in, revealing another gun pointing at his chest.
Riley picked himself up off the ground and said, “I am not amused by your antics Mr. Alex. I hope you understand that my good friend here, Mr. Morgan, is devoted to eliminating such irritations from my life.” At this, the large man contorted his face into what he might have intended as a smile. It made him look no less ugly. Riley continued, “Tie up Mr. Alex.”
Morgan forced Alex into a wooden arm chair and carefully pinned Alex in place by wrapping a piece of piano wire around each of the chair’s corners and Alex’s arms. Each subsequent twist of the wire bit more painfully into Alex’s flesh.
Morgan grunted to indicate that he was done. Riley said, “My dear Mr. Alex. The last time I held you in captivity, you were able to outwit my guard. He died soon after that in an automobile accident. Poor fellow. Morgan here will be responsible for you this time. He has orders to shoot you if you even attempt to speak to him.”

Alex smiled and said, “We must stop meeting like this Mr. Alex. I grow weary of pointing a gun at you.”
Before Alex could reply, a large bird crashed into the wall of glass that made up one side of Alex’s large office. Alex took advantage of the distraction to pull up one corner of the rug on which Alex stood. As Alex’s eyes grew accustomed to the dark of the office, he hurried toward the door. He was met there, however, by a very large and very ugly man. Light from the hall spilled in, revealing another gun pointing at his chest.

I hope you understand that my good friend here, Mr. Alex, is devoted to eliminating such irritations from my life.” At this, the large man contorted his face into what he might have intended as a smile. It made him look no less ugly. Alex continued, “Tie up Mr. Alex.”
Alex forced Alex into a wooden arm chair and carefully pinned Alex in place by wrapping a piece of piano wire around each of the chair’s corners and Alex’s arms. Each subsequent twist of the wire bit more painfully into Alex’s flesh.
Alex grunted to indicate that he was done. Alex said, “My dear Mr. Alex. The last time I held you in captivity, you were able to outwit my guard. He died soon after that in an automobile accident. Poor fellow. Alex here will be responsible for you this time.”

Morgan smiled and said, “We must stop meeting like this Mr. Jordan. I grow weary of pointing a gun at you.”
Before Jordan could reply, a large bird crashed into the wall of glass that made up one side of Morgan’s large office. Jordan took advantage of the distraction to pull up one corner of the rug on which Morgan stood. Morgan stumbled backwards and his gun shot up into the air, knocking out the large light that had illuminated the room.
As Jordan’s eyes grew accustomed to the dark of the office, he hurried toward the door. He was met there, however, by a very large and very ugly man. Light from the hall spilled in, revealing another gun pointing at his chest.
Morgan picked himself up off the ground and said, “I am not amused by your antics Mr. Jordan. I hope you understand that my good friend here, Mr. Jordan, is devoted to eliminating such irritations from my life.” At this, the large man contorted his face into what he might have intended as a smile. It made him look no less ugly. Morgan continued, “Tie up Mr. Jordan.”
Jordan forced Jordan into a wooden arm chair and carefully pinned Jordan in place by wrapping a piece of piano wire around each of the chair’s corners and Jordan’s arms. Each subsequent twist of the wire bit more painfully into Jordan’s flesh.
Jordan grunted to indicate that he was done. Morgan said, “My dear Mr. Jordan. You came here as my guest and now I find you going through my personal belongings. I don’t think you have behaved very well. I will leave you here with Mr. Jordan to contemplate your rude behavior.”
